repnme.cdata!: Kosovo - Energy Sector Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Energy Sector
            Technical Assistance Project for Kosovo was satisfactory,
            the sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. The lessons learned
            indicate that the project's successful outcome can be
            attributed to the following facts: The Term of Reference
            (TORs) were comprehensive and clear. The Consultants carried
            out all their work in Kosovo. The Consultants fielded a
            competent team and they were assisted by effective local
            participation. Detailed and multiple reviews were carried
            out by professional staff having the requisite expertise on
            behalf of the Bank, United Nations Interim Administration
            Mission in Kosovo (UNMIK), The Power Company of Kosovo
            (KEK), and the district heating companies, greatly
            contributed to the quality of the output. The timeframe for
            the study was realistic given the comprehensive nature of
            the study and the iterative approach required; sufficient
            time was available for regular exchange of views, and
            multiple reviews. The Consultants provided on-the-job
            training and transferred relevant software packages. The
            results of the Study were presented to a wide audience and
            feedback received was incorporated into the Final Report.

5087585.trustfund:
TF027791-KOSOVO ENERGY SECTOR TECHNICAL
            ASSISTANCE PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Kosovo, Federal Republic of Yugoslavia -
            Energy Sector Technical Assistance Project (Serbia and Montenegro)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Energy Sector Technical Assistance
            Project will assist in the development of satisfactory
            long-term plans, for the economically efficient
            reconstruction, rehabilitation, and restructuring of the
            power, lignite, and district heating, in addition to the
            petroleum sectors, and the development of a natural gas
            sector. The project consists of a technical assistance (TA)
            component to prepare an energy sector study. The study would
            have thirteen modules as follows: 1) develop a household
            energy survey to evaluate feasibility, and costs of
            alternative energy sources; 2) determine production
            capability of existing power generating facilities, and
            identify options for future power generating capacity; 3)
            prepare alternative programs for rehabilitation, and
            expansion of the power transmission system, and analyze
            least-cost power generation investments to determine
            expansion plans; 4) analyze technical losses in power
            transmission, and distribution, to propose immediate
            long-term measures on loss reduction targets, and costs; 5)
            evaluate the feasibility of a new System Control and Data
            Acquisition (SCADA), and associated telecommunications
            facilities for power system dispatching; 6) prioritize
            investment requirements in distribution capacity; 7) propose
            a lignite mine development strategy for supply to existing
            thermal power stations; 8) evaluate the current state of
            district heating facilities, and compare competitiveness
            with other heating options; 9) investigate the technical,
            and economic feasibility of importing natural gas to Kosovo,
            estimating gas demand, and required pipeline infrastructure;
            10) estimate future demand for petroleum products; 11) based
            on the above modules, prepare recommendations on investment
            plans for power and energy sub-sectors; 12) estimate
            economic costs of electricity, and tariff structures, based
            on least-cost generation/transmission programs; and, 13)
            examine the organizational, and operational structure of
            energy companies, including recommendations towards company
            autonomy, corporatization, commercialization, competition,
            and privatization.
